abstract.p: Christopher Meyer, co-author with Stan Davis of book Future Wealth, predicts workers may one day auction their available work time to the highest-bidding employer; foresees online market for 'human capital futures' (M)

block.p: First Beanie Babies and now this. People may one day auction their available work time to the highest-bidding employer, the authors of a new book predict.

''Suppose you're a graphic designer,'' said Christopher Meyer, co-author of ''Future Wealth'' (Harvard Business School Press, $27.50). ''You say, 'I'm going to sell 20 hours of my time in the first week of June.' You put that up on an Internet board and some employer comes in and buys it. You've traded a contract for a human capital future.''
First Beanie Babies and now this. People may one day auction their available work time to the highest-bidding employer, the authors of a new book predict.

''Suppose you're a graphic designer,'' said Christopher Meyer, co-author of ''Future Wealth'' (Harvard Business School Press, $27.50). ''You say, 'I'm going to sell 20 hours of my time in the first week of June.' You put that up on an Internet board and some employer comes in and buys it. You've traded a contract for a human capital future.''

Individuals will control their own destinies in tomorrow's labor market ''because they, and not their would-be employers, hold the desired resource,'' Mr. Meyer wrote with his co-author, Stan Davis. Even service and blue-collar workers, the authors said, will be able to auction their skills online and find work more easily.
